factoid: Five days passed.
Prince Nicholas Andréevich was baptized after five days.
The wet nurse supported the coverlet with her chin.
The priest used a goose feather to anoint Prince Nicholas Andréevich's little red and wrinkled soles and palms.
Prince Nicholas Andréevich's grandfather was his godfather.
The grandfather carried the infant around the battered tin font.
The grandfather was trembling and afraid of dropping the infant.
The grandfather handed Prince Nicholas Andréevich over to Princess Mary.
Prince Andrew sat in another room during the baptism ceremony.
Prince Andrew was faint with fear that the baby might drown in the font.
Prince Andrew awaited the termination of the ceremony.
The nurse brought the baby to Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew looked up joyfully at the baby.
The nurse told Prince Andrew that the wax with the baby's hair had not sunk in the font but had floated.
Prince Andrew nodded approval when the nurse told him about the wax.
Rostóv's share in Dólokhov's duel with Bezúkhov was hushed up by the old count.
Rostóv was appointed an adjutant to the governor general of Moscow.
Rostóv was not degraded to the ranks as he expected.
Rostóv could not go to the country with the rest of the family.
Rostóv was kept all summer in Moscow by his new duties.
Dólokhov recovered from his illness.
Rostóv became very friendly with Dólokhov during Dólokhov's convalescence.
Dólokhov lay ill at his mother's house.
Dólokhov's mother loved him passionately and tenderly.
Old Mary Ivánovna had grown fond of Rostóv because of his friendship to her Fédya.
Mary Ivánovna often talked to Dólokhov about her son.
Fédya loves Bezúkhov.
Fédya never says a word against Bezúkhov.
Bezúkhov got off scotfree from the duel.
Fédya had to bear the whole burden of the duel.
Bezúkhov has been reinstated.
Bezúkhov is considered a gallant son of the fatherland.
The duel involved Bezúkhov challenging an only son.
The duel involved shooting straight.
Dólokhov says people consider him a bad man.
Dólokhov says he does not care a straw about anyone but those he loves.
Dólokhov says he loves those he loves so he would give his life for them.
Dólokhov says he would throttle others if they stood in his way.
Dólokhov says he has an adored, priceless mother.
Dólokhov says he has two or three friends, including Rostóv.
Dólokhov says he only cares about the rest as far as they are harmful or useful.
Dólokhov says most of them are harmful, especially women.
Dólokhov says he has met loving, noble, high-minded men.
Dólokhov says he has not yet met any women who were not venal.
Dólokhov says he has not yet met divine purity and devotion he looks for in women.
Dólokhov says if he found such a woman he would give his life for her.
Dólokhov made a gesture of contempt.
Dólokhov says he still values his life because he hopes to meet a divine creature who will regenerate, purify, and elevate him.
Dólokhov says the other person does not understand it.
Rostóv answered that he quite understands.
Rostóv was under Dólokhov's influence.
